Recently, the traditional description of synoptic systems—and more generally atmospheric configurations—has been complemented by a novel approach issued from dynamical systems theory. This is grounded in the seminal work of Lorenz (
13 ,
14 ) and is based on metrics describing the instantaneous state of atmospheric fields (
15 ). Contrary to this, previous dynamical systems approaches focused on the mean properties of the atmosphere, with limited applications in the context of atmospheric variability (
16 ). Faranda et al. (
15 ) have shown that key instantaneous properties of an atmospheric field can be summarized by two metrics: the local dimension ( d) and the persistence of the state being considered (θ −1). The value of d for a given atmospheric state ξ is a proxy for the number of active degrees of freedom and provides information on the state’s intrinsic predictability (
15 ). θ −1 is instead a measure of average persistence time of the atmosphere around that state. For discrete time data, the value of θ will depend on the dataset’s time step. If an atmospheric state ξ is a fixed point of the dynamics, θ(ξ) = 0. For a trajectory that leaves the neighborhood of state ξ immediately, θ(ξ) = 1. Accordingly, low d and high θ −1 (or low θ) imply a high predictability state and vice versa. Full details of how d and θ are computed are provided in the Methods.
